instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A that has no power.

It tries to power on (goes to 350mA, and drops to 25mA), but doesn't power on.

The region arround <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> was corroded and I ireplaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and <RESISTOR>R8167</RESISTOR> but without success.

On <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> I get 3.4V on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> but 0V on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
No pulse at all at <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>?
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and check again.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: I get a pulse of 2.8V, but immediately drops to 0V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Pin 3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pulse at same time?
If not, remove <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and check for corrosion.
If yes, check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I have pulses on pin3 of <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and on  <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> too.
I already replaced <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>, and cleaned the pads (no corrosion).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and check again."
Did that?

Also try SMC bypass.
Check all SPI Bus Termination resistros and their traces; clean J6100 too.
Try known good BIOS.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
HI,

I did removed <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR>, but with the same result. Now I've soldered it again.
SMC bypass didn''t worked either.
All SPI Bus Termination resistors are ok.
J6100  is clean and with no corrosion.
With a clean ME BIOS, the same result.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Then probably bad CPU.
You can try heating it with quality flux; maybe just accumulated crap.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
OK, tks.
What temp and heat time do you recommend?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: 180-200 C degrees, no more than 15-20s...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: TKS!

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Before I heat the CPU (haven't done it yet), I took a look in the thermal cam, and the only thing that gets hot is the area arround <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>, and it seams that <CAPACITOR>C7150</CAPACITOR> gets a bit hotter (not shorted and has 8,59V on both pins), and the <CHIP>U4650</CHIP> area was a bit corroded (already cleaned it). Do you think that this mean something related with the problem?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
After heating the CPU, and making a ultra sound cleaning, now i don't have <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> (0V).
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
After heating the CPU and making an ultra-sound, now I don't get <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> (0V), but I have <SIGNAL>PP5_S5</SIGNAL>
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Seems that you make use of UC more than needed.
At least test the boards before the process.

I suspect knocked off components, or broken trace.
Also possible CPU damaged, if overheated.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Tks for the tip about UC. I've done it because of the CPU flux (I've used a lot).
I don't think that I've overheated the CPU (but not sure), and I can't see broken components.
Any idea of the major traces that I should look for?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Try reballing SMC, as last option...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
I've rebaled SMC but same result. It tries to power on (no fan spin), goes to 0.350mA, and drops to 0.25mA.

I have 0V on  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL>  and 0V on  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>. 

On <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> I get 3.3V but on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> I only get 0.324V.

Do you think that is the CPU?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Very likely bad PCH/CPU...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: OK. TKS.
